title: The Corpus Luteum of the Guinea Pig. Fine Structure at the Time of Maximum Progesterone Secretion and during Regression 1
abstract: This report describes the fine structure of guinea pig luteal cells during the period of maximum progesterone secretion and throughout involution, in ovaries that have been fixed by perfusion, a technique that provides optimal preservation of steroid-secreting tissues. abstract.text: This report describes the fine structure of guinea pig luteal cells during the period of maximum progesterone secretion and throughout involution, in ovaries that have been fixed by perfusion, a technique that provides optimal preservation of steroid-secreting tissues. Smooth endoplasmic reticulum (smooth Accepted June 8, '11.

body_text.text: ER), a prominent organelle in these cells, is particularly well preserved by this method of fixation. During the time of maximal progesterone secretion, luteal cells contain abundant tubules and cisternae of smooth ER, many mitochondria, a well-developed Golgi complex and some lipid droplets. This fine structural picture is consistent with active steroidogenesis.

Autophagy plays an important role in the regression of luteal cells in the corpus luteum. The onset of luteolysis is marked by the appearance of structurally complex autophagic vacuoles, one of which has not been described previously in luteal cells. This autophagic vacuole seems to originate from GERL (Golgi-endoplasmic reticulum-lysosomes) as a cup-shaped structure, which subsequently increases in size and complexity. Regressing luteal cells also contain increased numbers of both dense bodies (lysosomes) and lipid droplets, and exhibit changes in nuclear and mitochondria1 morphology. In contrast to previous reports in the literature, changes in the morphology of smooth ER were not observed as a characteristic feature of involution in corpora lutea of guinea pigs in the present study. Advanced regression of luteal cells is characterized by multiple fusion of lipid droplets and a decrease in the amount of smooth ER.

Another mechanism active in the breakdown of the corpus luteum is the phagocytosis of luteal cells by macrophages. Although present a t all stages, macrophages are most abundant in older corpora lutea, where they often surround dead or dying luteal cells.

The corpus luteum of the ovary is a tissue ideally suited for the study of cellular regression because, following their appearance, mature luteal cells synthesize and secrete steroid hormones for a limited period, then degenerate in response to hormones produced by the uterus and eventually disappear. The involution of cells in response to physiological signals is of general interest. Although the degeneration of luteal cells has been described for a number of mammalian species, the mechanisms underlying this normal involution are still imperfectly understood. Major fine structural studies have dealt with human (Adams and Hertig, '69; van Lennep and Madden, '65; Green and Maqueo, , 651, rabbit (Blanchette, AM. J. ANAT. (1977) 150: 566-604. '66) . hamster (Leavitt et al., '73) sheep (Deane et al., '66; Bjersing et al., '70a, b; Gemmell et al., '761, cow (Priedkalns and Webeq '68) and sow (Bjersing, '67; Cavazos et al., '69) . Some observations have also been published on regression of guinea pig corpus luteum (Crombie et al., '71; Bourneva, '73) , although the process has not been studied in depth in this species.

Cellular self-destruction (autophagy) and removal of cells by macrophages (heterophagy) seem to be involved in the regression of corpora lutea, but the contribution of each to the dissolution of the corpus luteum has not been clearly defined. In addition, a1 though several fine structural studies have shown that autophagic vacuoles appear within luteal cells a t the time of regression, the origin of these vacuoles remains controversial. Several organelles have been implicated as the source of the membranes that enclose autlDphagic vacuoles in various tissues, including the Golgi complex (Frank and Christenslen, '68; Locke and Sykes, '751 , smooth endoplaiimic reticulum (Novikoff and Shin, '64; Arstila and Trump, '68) , GERL (Golgi-endoplasmic reticulum-lysosomes) (Novikoff, '64) and plasma membrane (van Lennep and Madden, '65; Quatacker, '71). Thus, it is evident that the involution of the corpus luteum deserves further attention. A careful fine structural analysis of regression in optimally preserved corpus luteum, followed by the cytochemical localization of appropriate marker enzymes, e.g., acid phosphatase, a lysosomal enzyme, should yield insight into how luteal cells degenerate. However, both fine structural and cytochemical studies are hampered by the fact that steroid-secreting cells are difficult to prepare for electron microscopy. The method used to fix the tissue has a profound effect on the quality of' preservation, especially that of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (smooth ER). Steroid-secreting cells when fixed by immersion generally show considerable variation in the preservation of cellular fine structure and often contain vesicular smooth ER. On the other hand, perfusion of the fixative through steroid-secreting tissues produces consistently superior morphology, and the smootlh ER is usually maintained in its characteristic tubular or cisternal form (Christensen, '65) . In order to obtain optimally fixed material for this study, a method was developed that allows corpora lutea to be fixed in situ by perfusion of the fixative through the ovary.

The guinea pig was selected as the experimental animal because it has particularly well-developed corpora lutea and, in addition, a voluminous literature exists that defines the hormonal status of this animal during both normal and many experimentally-induced reproductive states. Previous studies on guinea pig corpus luteum have been carried out on immersion-fixed material (Crombie et al., '71; PAAVOLA Bourneva, '73) . Since the smooth ER, the most prominent organelle in these cells, is difficult to preserve by this approach, it is valuable to re-examine and extend those observations in material fixed by perfusion.

In the present study the fine structure of normal and regressing luteal cells is examined in detail. The findings differ in several respects from those of earlier studies. For example, in contrast to the earlier observation that dissolution of the smooth ER was a prominent feature of involution, the results of this study indicate that the smooth ER remains unchanged in form throughout the greater part of regression. In addition, an unusual autophagic vacuole is described that apparently arises from GERL and appears to play an important role in involution. The fine structural description presented here establishes the morphological basis for luteolysis and thereby will serve as a framework for later cytochemical studies.

The Hartley guinea pigs used in this study were obtained from Perfection Breeders (Douglassville, Pennsylvania). The stage of pregnancy was verified by the size and external morphology of the fetuses (Draper, '20; Ibsen, '28; Harman and Prickett, '32; Harman and Dobrovolny, '33; Scott, '36) , a method that determines the actual age of the fetus, and thus times the pregnancy as accurately as dated matings. Corpora lutea were secured from seven pregnant animals a t 25 to 33 days, two at 40 to 50 days, and six a t 60 to 68 days, and from four animals each a t 5, 10 and 16 days portpartum.

In the early phase of this work, the effects of several different fixative-buffer combinations on luteal cell fine structure were compared and it was found that the following fixative consistently gave the best results: 1% paraformaldehyde-1 % glutaraldehyde-0.0 1 % 2,4,6trinitrocresol (It0 and Karnovsky, '68) in 0.1 M cacodylate buffer. High-purity glutaraldehyde was purchased from Tousimis Research Corporation (Rockville, Maryland).

All corpora lutea examined in this study were fixed in situ by perfusion of the fixative through the blood vessels of the ovary. A Holter peristaltic pump (Extracorporeal Medical Specialties, Inc., King of Prussia, Pennsylvania; model 911, fitted with size D pump chambers) was used to deliver the various solutions to the ovary, and a 26-gauge needle was used as a cannula. Prior to surgery, the guinea pigs were anesthetized by an intraperitoneal injection of sodium pentobarbital (30-35 m g k g body weight).

The perfusion procedure is presented in some detail because it is rather involved and variations in the protocol may Pesult in less favorable preservation of the tissue. Each ovary was perfused independently of the other, which necessitated opening the abdomen with a U-shaped incision that extended from the pubis to the ribs. A ligature (4-0 surgical silk) was placed around both the ovarian artery and vein, and tied loosely in an overhand knot. A length of the uterine artery was carefully separated from its companion vein, and a second ligature was tied loosely around the artery. Ligatures were placed in similar locations around the vessels of the contralateral ovary. The uterine artery was grasped somewhat caudal to the ligature with fine forceps, lifted and pulled slightly taut. The cannula, with Krebs-Ringer-bicarbonate buffer (containing 2 mg/ml glucose, pH 7.4, 300 mOsm.) flowing from it a t a rate of 2.0 ml/min, was inserted into the uterine artery, guided past the ligature and secured into place by tightening the ligature. Then, in rapid sequence, a nick was made in the uterine vein to provide an outflow for the perfusate, and the ligature around the ovarian artery and vein was tightened, isolating the ovary from the circulatory system. After a 2-to 3-minute buffer wash, fixation was begun and continued for 10 to 30 minutes. Within a very short time after the fixative reached the ovary, the latter had begun to harden, indicating a favorable perfusion. After the perfusion was underway on one side, perfusion of the contralateral ovary was begun, following the same sequence. Attempts to perfuse the ovary through the abdominal aorta yielded results that were less consistent than those obtained by the method described here.

Following perfusion-fixation, the ovaries were removed and the corpora lutea were excised, cleared of nonluteal tissue, sliced and placed either in fresh fixative for an additional 30 to 60 minutes or directly into buffer (0.1 M cacodylate, pH 7.4, containing 5% sucrose). After the buffer wash, the slices were minced into smaller pieces, post-fixed in cold 1.33% OsO,-O.O67 M cacodylate containing 5% sucrose for one hour, rinsed briefly in buffer, stained en block with cold buffered uranyl acetate (Farquhar and Palade, '65) a t pH 6 for one hour in the dark, rinsed briefly in buffer, dehydrated in graded ethanols and flat-embedded in epoxy resin (Spurr, '69) . Pale gold to silver thin sections were prepared with a diamond knife, stained in lead citrate for 30 seconds to 2 minutes (Reynolds, '63) and viewed at 60 KV in a Philips 300 electron microscope fitted with a 20-pm aperture.

The following general observations apply to all corpora lutea examined in this study. The corpus luteum of the guinea pig was composed of one type of lutein cell, since granulosa lutein and theca lutein cells are indistinguishable following luteinization in this animal (Loeb, '061, also present were fibroblasts and macrophages. The light and dark varieties of luteal cells that have been described in immersion-fixed tissue (Crombie et al., '71) were not observed a t any stage in perfusionfixed material of the present study. Blood vessels pervaded the corpus luteum, but lymphatic vessels were not observed within the corpus luteum proper, although they were found between the connective tissue elements of the theca. Lymphatic vessels can be identified relatively easily in tissue that has been fixed by perfusion, since they contain a flocculent material, whereas blood vessels are empty. Occasionally, the fixative used in this study caused some shrinkage of cells.

The fine structure of luteal cells a t 25 to 33, 40 to 50, and 60 to 68 days of pregnancy and a t 5,lO and 16 days postpartum will be described in the following sections. Descriptions of later stages will focus on changes that have taken place. Throughout this report, membranelimited bodies containing one or more cellular constituents were classified as autophagic vacuoles.

Days 25-33 ofgestation (time of maximum progesterone secretion) At 25 to 33 days of pregnancy, the corpus luteum was composed primarily of large, polygonal luteal cells (fig. l). At the electron microscopic level the most conspicuous organelle was the smooth ER, which filled most of the available cytoplasm (fig. 3 ). In perfused material of the present study, these membranes commonly were in the form of densely-packed, interwoven, 50-nm tubules, that repeatedly branched and anastomosed. Often the tubules of smooth ER were long, relatively straight and aligned parallel to each other; in favora-ble sections, they exhibited a hexagonal closepacking pattern (fig. 4 ). Smooth EtR also formed sheets (cisternae), perforated hy many evenly-spaced fenestrations (fig. 5 ). These cisternae were commonly organized in 2 to 25 concentric layers (whorls) around oither organelles, particularly lipid droplets. Cisternal and tubular smooth ER communicated freely with each other. Rough endoplasmic reticulum (rough ER) was moderately abundant, occurring as individual cisternae or as small patches of parallel cisternae (fig. 6 ). Numerous continuities existed between the membranes of rough ER and those of smooth ER (fig. 6 ).

Tubules and cisternae of smooth E: R were neither dilated nor vesiculated in perfusionfixed luteal cells of the present study. This is in contrast to descriptions of immersbon-fixed luteal cells of guinea pigs (Crombie et al. , '71; Bourneva, '73) and other species, where vesicular smooth ER and widened tubules have been encountered frequently. This suggests that these other forms of smooth ER may have been artifacts that arose during immersion fixation.

The prominent Golgi complex was dispersed throughout the cytoplasm as stacks, each consisting of four to six parallel, flattened cisternae (figs. 8, 9). The cisternae appeared to be empty, perhaps because their content had been extracted. Golgi cisternae sometimes exhibited coated vesicles a t their edges.

Characteristic smooth-surfaced membranes occurred along the inner (trans) face of the Golgi complex (figs. 9-11). In position and morphology these smooth membrane13 resembled the GERL system described in rat neurons by Novikoff et al. ('71) . GERL cisternae in luteal cells usually followed the contours of a Golgi stack, being separated from the inner element by a narrow region of cytoplasm (fig. 9 ); less frequently they formed cup-shaped structures. The GERL membrane itself often appeared thickened when compared with the membranes of most other organelles (fig. 11 ). Coated vesicles were commonly attached to GERL (fig. 10 ). Occasionally electron-lucent vacuoles and many 40-nm vesicles, both smooth-surfaced and coated, occurred in the Golgi-GERL region and elsewhere.

Luteal cells of this stage in guinea pigs, as in other species, contained numerous cytoplasmic inclusions. Dense bodies (lysosomes) were modest in number. Only a few displayed a ho-mogeneous matrix, and they were usually round or oval in shape (fig. 12 ). Since these bodies are acid phosphatase (ACPase) -positive (Paavola, '75), they were considered to be primary lysosomes. Most of the dense bodies were residual bodies, which contained one or more myelin figures (fig. 13 ). Some of the residual bodies were also ACPase-positive (Paavola, '75). Autophagic vacuoles were rare a t this stage. Microperoxisome-like bodies, which were abundant, ranged in diameter from 0.05- 0.18 pm, were limited by a single membrane, contained a finely granular matrix and lacked a core or nucleoid (fig. 7 ). These inclusions often congregated near lipid droplets (fig. 7 ). Cytochemical incubation confirmed t h a t these bodies contained catalase (Paavola, '75). Several multivesicular bodies were present in each section of a luteal cell. These bodies contained small vesicles embedded in a matrix which varied considerably in density. Their limiting membranes sometimes displayed short, thickened patches (fig. 141 , which appeared to have arisen by fusion with coated vesicles. Possible stages in such a process were observed, confirming other similar observations in the literature. Lipid droplets, which were few in number, often occupied the center of whorls of smooth ER (fig. 5 ). Some lipid droplets were fully or partially extracted by the solvents used to prepare the tissue for electron microscopy, whereas others remained intact.

At this time of peak steroid secretion, mitochondria were abundant, rod-shaped, and displayed a moderately dense matrix which con tained both tubular and lamellar cristae; thus, they resembled those described by Crombie et al. ('71). Mitochondria1 matrix granules were not conspicuous a t 25 to 33 days of pregnancy. Luteal cells of this age contained numerous single microtubules (fig. 3 ) and bundles of microfilaments (fig. 15 ) that coursed randomly through the cell. Their plasma membranes displayed short, irregular microvilli, gap junctions (fig. 16 ) and desmosomelike junctions (fig. 17 ). In the case of the latter, the inner leaflets of the apposing plasma membranes were thickened locally, but obvious tonofilaments were lacking. Coated vesicles occurred subjacent to the plasma membrane, and coated pits, either singly or in clusters, dotted the plasmalemma. The more or less oval nucleus contained sparse heterochromatin (fig. 31 , occasional perichromatin granules (fig. 3 ) and one to three prominent nucleoli.

Days 40-50 of gestation The fine structure of luteal cells a t 40 to 50 days of pregnancy was similar to that described for the previous stage. However, some minor changes were evident, e.g., the number of lipid droplets had increased in most luteal cells. Occasional luteal cells of this stage contained unusual autophagic vacuoles which were not observed in the previous stage. Since they were few in number a t this time, their morphology is described with the next stage (near term), when they were more abundant.

Although many luteal cells in near-term corpora lutea exhibited a fine structure basically similar to that described for lutein cells of earlier stages, others displayed conspicuous changes in their ultrastructure that seemed to anticipate regression. The most striking of these changes was the accumulation of numerous structurally-complex autophagic vacuoles in the cytoplasm of some cells. Other important changes included a more extensive development of GERL, an increase in the number of dense bodies (lysosomes) and lipid droplets, and alterations in nuclear and mitochondria1 morphology. Since these changes typify involution, as will become evident a t later stages, they will be described in detail below.

In marked contrast to corpora lutea a t 25 to 33 days of pregnancy, some luteal cells near term contained many membrane-bound bodies which could be classified as autophagic vacuoles, since they appeared to contain cytoplasmic components. These autophagic vacuoles, first observed in limited number in occasional luteal cells at 40 to 50 days of gestation, varied considerably in morphology, and thus could be divided roughly into four types, each of which will now be described. The most unusual and complex of the autophagic vacuoles seen in the present study, the intricate type (figs. 18, 19, 26, 27), has not been described previously in luteal cells. These distinctive, labyrinthine structures were composed of several electron-dense portions interconnected by double membranes. The double membranes were unusual in that the small space separating them contained a central dense line embedded in a moderately dense material (fig. 19 ). The spaces (compartments) delineated by the double membranes often contained ER, ribosomes and dense bodies (figs. 18, 19, 26). In many instances, the double membranes were observed in a less complex configuration; e.g., they occurred as independent, ring-or U-shaped entities that partially or completely surrounded various cytoplasmic organelles (figs. 18, 23 24 25 29 ). This double-membrane form of autophagic vacuole became more numerous after birth and will be discussed further in the section on 16 days postpartum. Near-term luteal cells contained yet another type of large, complex autophagic vacuole (fig. 30 ). This aggregate type autophagic vacuole was limited by a single membrane and usually contained many closelypacked, predominantly spherical bodies of varying size and electron-density, some of which appeared to be myelin figures (fig. 30 ). This inclusion resembled the "multivesicular" autophagic vacuole described briefly by Crombie et al. ('71) in an earlier report on guinea pig luteal cells. Lipid droplets and ribosomes commonly occurred within the aggregate autophagic vacuole. In addition to these more elaborate forms of autophagic vacuoles, nearterm luteal cells also contained a fourth type, similar in morphology to those described in many other cell types. This simple autophagic vacuole (fig. 28 ) appeared to be surrounded by a single membrane and most frequently contained ER. Although these simple autophagic vacuoles were seen a t all stages of pregnancy and postpartum, there was, a t most, one or two per section of cell, and there was no apparent increase in their number as involution progressed. The autophagic nature of the intricate, double-membrane and aggregate inclusions was confirmed by cytochemical incubation for ACPase activity (Paavola, '75). The simple autophagic vacuole generally lacked ACPase activity (Paavola, unpublished observations) .

Although the Golgi complex was unchanged from earlier stages, the associated GERL membranes were more conspicuous in near term luteal cells, perhaps because they were better developed a t this time. Near term, the GERL cisternae sometimes showed modifications that suggested they may give rise to certain autophagic vacuoles. As a t earlier stages, GERL was associated with a Golgi stack (fig.

201, either being adjacent to or some distance from the inner face. Occasional GERL cisternae contained a moderately dense material (figs. 21, 22) . These "modified' GERL cisternae, which were not present a t earlier stages, closely resembled the double-membrane inclusions described above, and intermediates (figs. 21-23) suggest that these "modified" GERL cisternae may possibly be precursors of autophagic vacuoles (DISCUSSION).

When compared with earlier stage,s, both dense bodies (lysosomes) and lipid droplets had become more numerous. The number of dense bodies had increased substantially in some, but not all, near-term luteal cells. They were heterogeneous in size and shape, including spherical, oval and dumbell-shaped forms (fig. 29 ). These dense bodies, along with autophagic vacuoles, often clustered near the plasma membrane (figs. 18, 29) . A dramatic increase in the number of lipid droplets had occurred and the cytoplasm of most luteal cells was crowded with them, confirming similar observations in other species. All lipid droplets within a given luteal cell generally had one of these four appearances: non-extracted, partially-extracted, fully-extracted or flocculent. However, some cells contained a mixture of these types.

Other changes noted in near-term corpora lutea were alterations in mitochondrial and nuclear morphology. Although their fine structure was unaltered, the incidence of nuclei with markedly irregular contours or deep indentations had increased appreciably. Mitochondria remained plentiful in near-term luteal cells, and although many were unchanged from previous stages, others had undergone marked changes in shape. Bizarre configurations were observed, including mitochondria that were branched, unusually sinuous, cup-shaped or extremely long and much attenuated (figs. 31, 32) . Serial sections confirmed that the cup-shaped varieties partially or completely surrounded lipid diroplets, bits of cytoplasm and each other. These polymorphic mitochondria often clustered near the periphery of the cell. The mitochondrial matrix appeared to have increased in density, and frequently the cristae assumed a re- markably highly-ordered arrangemlent, in which the lamellae or tubules lay parallel to each other (fig. 32 ). Matrix granules were prominent in some mitochondria of thii3 stage, whereas a t earlier stages they were not conspicuous.

I t should be re-emphasized that only a certain proportion of near-term luteal cells displayed the changes which characterize involu-PA AVO LA tion, such as autophagic vacuoles, pleomorphic mitochondria and increased numbers of dense bodies (lysosomes). Although many near-term luteal cells exhibited one or more of these features to a varying degree, some cells still resembled those described in the 25-to 33-day corpus luteum. Even in subsequent stages of progressive involution, there remained a certain number, continuously decreasing, of luteal cells that exhibited approximately the original morphology. Only in the terminal stages of degeneration were these cells no longer found.

Smooth ER was relatively abundant in luteal cells of near-term animals and, as in previous stages, it occurred in the form of tubules and cisterane. Cisternal smooth ER still formed whorls around some lipid droplets. The remaining organelles showed no changes in their fine structure.

When luteal cells of this time period were viewed in low-power electron micrographs, lipid droplets and large dense bodies were often the most conspicuous features (fig. 2 ). The alterations toward involution that distinguished some luteal cells of near-term corpora lutea were more evident a t 5 days portpartum, since by that time they were exhibited by more cells. Thus, many cells of this stage contained numerous dense bodies (lysosomes) , autophagic vacuoles and polymorphic mitochondria (fig. 331 , most of which resembled their counterparts of the previous stage.

Since regression was intensified in the 5-day-postpartum corpus luteum, additional details of involution, not obvious in near-term luteal cells, were noted. For example, in contrast to those observed in younger corpora lutea, lysosomes in regressing luteal cells were often highly pleomorphic. The beaded lysosome, shown in figures 33 and 34, was one of the many unusual forms present during involution. These bodies were ACPase-positive in cytochemical preparations (Paavola, '75) .

Other aspects of regression that unfolded a t five days postpartum involved lipid droplets and mitochondria. As a t near term, lipid droplets occurred in large numbers and varied in their extractibility by solvents (figs. 33, 361, but by five days postpartum they were fre- quently noted within autophagic vacuoles (fig. 361 , some of which also contained one or more electron-dense crystals or small, thick-walled tubules (fig. 38 ). In some cases, lysosome-like structures surrounded or appeared to be fusing with lipid droplets (fig. 35 ). Occasional lipid droplets were observed in the extracellular space, and since they resembled those within luteal cells it is likely that they had been extruded, an event uncommon in younger corpora lutea.

Mitochondria, resembling those of the preceding stage in external form, displayed striking crystalline inclusions within their cristae (fig. 37 ) or outer compartments. These inclusions, not previously reported in luteal cells, exhibited a distinctive, regularly-repeating substructure. Matrix granules were obvious a t this stage. Occasionally, much enlarged mitochondria were observed.

Smooth ER tubules and cisternae retained their usual dimensions and configurations in intact, perfusion-fixed luteal cells a t five days postpartum (figs. 33, 36). No changes in the fine structure of the remaining organelles were observed.

By five days postpartum, the number of luteal cells showing obvious deterioration had increased. These moribund cells occurred in all stages examined, but prior to five days postpartum, they were few in number. All or- ganelles in these grossly altered cells were distorted (fig. 39 ), often being barely recognizable. Most commonly these degenerate luteal cells were surrounded by a macrophage (fig. 39 ).

Day 10 postpartum By ten days postpartum, a larger proportion of the remaining luteal cells displayed those features characteristic of involution. A typical luteal cell of this stage contained an indented nucleus, many small and mediumsized dense bodies (lysosomes), autophagic vacuoles and oddly-shaped mitochondria with parallel cristae and crystalline inclusions (fig. 40 ). Unusually elongated lysosome-like structures (fig. 40 : arrows, inset) were common in these later stages of involution. They were slender, usually only about 0.1 p m in diameter, and were observed extending up to 3 pm in length. These elongated structures were ACPase-positive following cytochemical incubation (Paavola, '75). Lipid droplets remained a prominent feature in many lutein cells.

In a number of cells a t ten days postpartum, mitochondria were the most conspicuous organelle, filling much of the cytoplasm (fig. 41 ). Most of these mitochondria-laden cells were small, and tended to contain fewer lipid droplets and less smooth ER than did other luteal cells. Similar mitochondria-enriched cells were observed occasionally a t earlier stages of regression.

In perfused material, both tubular and cisternal smooth ER maintained their typical configurations even a t ten days postpartum. Whorls, often large, of smooth ER encircled some lipid droplets. Thus, these observations differ from those of others in immersion-fixed tissue, where the smooth ER was described as being in the process of disintegration (Crombie et al., '71) and the whorls were said to be reduced in size a t earlier stages (Crombie et al., '71; Bourneva, "73).

Corpora lutea a t 16 days postpartum were greatly reduced in size when compared with those of preceding stages. Only a few luteal cells remained a t this advanced stage of involution, and these few contained a variable number of lipid droplets, numerous lysosomes and abundant autophagic vacuoles, largely similar to those previously described. Debrisladen macrophages were prominent in these much regressed corpora lutea, and appeared to have increased in number since earlier stages. Fibroblasts were also conspicuous. I t should be noted that there was more variation in the extent of regression among corpora lutea secured from different animals a t later stages of involution than a t earlier ones. For example, the 16-day specimens ranged from one corpus luteum in which virtually all luteal cells had degenerated, to another that contained an unusual number of comparatively intact cells.

Double-membrane autophagic vacuoles, which commonly contained ER, ribosomes, lysosomes, and ground substance, were particularly abundant during the terminal phases of regression. The extent and variety of these bodies is illustrated in figures 42 and 43. One might suspect that such double-membrane profiles could result from an appropriate plane of section through the more complex intricate autophagic vacuoles. However, serial sections (fig. 45 ) showed that many of the double-membrane figures observed in regressing luteal cells were independent, roughly spherical structures, distinct from intricate autophagic vacuoles. In a similar vein, it might be claimed that the pockets of cytoplasm which appear to be sequestered within intricate autophagic vacuoles might. merely be tongues of cytoplasm protruding into deep recesses indenting the surface of these bodies. However, here again, serial sections demonstrated that the compartments were partitioned from the remaining cytoplasm by an uninterrupted membranous wall. Material from 16-day-postpartum animals was used for the studies of serial sections since doublemembrane and intricate autophagic vacuoles were particularly numerous a t this time. These findings should also apply to the corresponding bodies seen a t earlier stages, since their similarity in electron micrographs leaves no reason to doubt that they represent the same structures.

Another characteristic feature of aldvanced involution was the apparent change in the properties of lipid droplets. Throughout earlier stages, lipid droplets usually occurred as individual structures, all of which were about the same size. However, by 16 days postpartum many lipid droplets appeared to have fused with each other, giving rise to the huge lipid droplets observed in some lutein cells (fig. 44 ).

For the first time, the smooth ER in most luteal cells showed signs of deterioraltion. Although tubules and cisternae were still present, they generally appeared sparse, dispersed and more indistinct (fig. 42 ) than a t previous stages. Even a t 16 days postpartum there was no tendency toward enlargement or vesiculation of the tubules or cisternae. In a few luteal cells, the smooth ER was remarkably normal in appearance and whorls of smooth ER still surrounded some lipid droplets (fig. 46 ), accentuating the fact that the involution of these cells was not synchronous, and even in advanced regression occasional cells were seen that had not yet degenerated.
No nuclear fragmentation was observed even a t this late stage of luteolysiai, in contrast to observations made in the ewe (Bjersing et al., '70a).

The findings of this study differ in several important respects from those of earlier studies (Crombie et al., '71; Bourneva, '73 ) and they provide additional information that expands our current understanding of how cells regress in response to physiological stimuli. The present study indicates that luteal cells of guinea pigs exhibit striking changes in their fine structure throughout their lifespan and PAAVOLA that these alterations can be correlated, a t least to some extent, with variations in the functional capacity of this tissue.

In guinea pigs, the corpus luteum functions maximally in the production and release of progesterone from about day 20 to day 35 (Heap et al., '67; Challis et al., '71) , a period when the ovaries are essential for pregnancy to continue (Deanesly, '60; Heap and Deanesly, '66) . After 30 to 35 days of gestation, the placenta supplies enough progesterone to support pregnancy, and although the corpus luteum continues to synthesize and secrete progesterone for some time, the ovaries are no longer required (Heap and Deanesly, '66) . From 35 days on, the contribution of the corpus luteum to total plasma progesterone declines steadily, and by 60 to 65 days of pregnancy, the level of plasma progesterone is the same in ovariectomized and intact animals, indicating that the amount of hormone released from the corpus luteum is negligible (Heap and Deanesly, '66) . However, even though the corpus luteum does not secrete progesterone, it contains appreciable amounts of the steroid (Heap et al., '67) . Shortly after birth of the young, plasma progesterone drops precipitously, a decline caused by loss of the placenta, and the plasma concentration remains low for about 48 hours, until the next corpus luteum, formed after parturition, begins secreting progesterone in measurable amounts (Challis et al., '71) . By 12 to 13 days postpartum, the progesterone content of the old corpus luteum of pregnancy is a t a minimum (Heap et al., '67) .

The ultrastructural modifications observed in luteal cells throughout pregnancy and the postpartum period in the present study seem to parallel these hormonal changes. For example, when progesterone secretion is maximal, a t 25 to 33 days of gestation, luteal cells of guinea pigs contain abundant tubules and cisternae of smooth ER, numerous mitochondria, a well-developed Golgi complex and occasional lipid droplets. Such ultrastructural features are characteristic of cells that are actively engaged in the synthesis and secretion of steroid hormones (Christensen and Gillim, '69) . Between 40 and 68 days of pregnancy, the amount of progesterone secreted by the corpus luteum gradually wanes. During this same period, a growing number of luteal cells display changes in their fine structure that seem to anticipate regression. Since the alterations in ultrastructure coincide tem-porally with the decreasing secretory activity of this tissue, it is tempting to suggest that the changing functional state is reflected in the fine structure. Near term, luteal cells of pregnant guinea pigs still contain relatively abundant smooth ER, when the progesterone content of the tissue is high but the ovarian contribution to plasma progesterone is slight. Throughout the postpartum period, an increasing number of luteal cells show regressive changes, such as bizarre mitochondria, pleomorphic dense bodies (lysosomes) and abundant autophagic vacuoles. The smooth ER is sparse in most postpartum luteal cells, and correspondingly the progesterone content of the tissue has reached its lowest value.

Prostaglandin F k , the hormone responsible for the involution of the corpus luteum in many species, brings about luteolysis in the guinea pig (Blatchley and Donovan, '69; Blatchley et al., '71, '72, '75; Poyser et al., '71; Poyser, '72; Maule-Walker and Poyser, '74). The present observations indicate that morphological regression of the corpus luteum proceeds slowly in this animal, continuing for 16 days or longer after birth of the young. Throughout this period, luteal cells degenerate asynchronously. Some luteal cells also involute sporadically during pregnancy but the number is low, accelerating markedly only after parturition. This protracted decline of the corpus luteum allows the degenerative changes occurring a t the cellular level to be considered in a temporal context. The results of this study indicate that as an individual luteal cell degenerates, whether prenatally or postnatally, it displays a characteristic sequence of fine-structural changes: First, autophagic vacuoles appear in the cytoplasm. Then, lysosomes accumulate, and alterations in nuclear and mitochondrial morphology occur. Later, unusual forms of lysosomes appear, mitochondria may enlarge or develop crystalline inclusions, and lipid droplets are sometimes extruded from the cell. In advanced regression, lipid droplets fuse with each other, autophagic vacuoles accumulate and the amount of smooth ER diminishes. Some luteal cells undergo a final step in luteolysis, an abrupt disintegration, with all organelles deteriorating simultaneously. Ultimately, the cell is ingested by a macrophage, a fate that can also befall luteal cells a t earlier stages in their involution (Paavola, '77) .

Clearly, the most striking change that takes place during this regression is the appearance and accumulation of distinctive cytoplasmic bodies that appear to be involved in autophagy, namely the intricate, double-membrane and aggregate inclusions. These structures first emerge, in limited numbers, in the last third of pregnancy, are more common near term and are particularly abundant postpartum. Cytochemical studies a t the electron microscope level reveal that these bodies contain pronounced ACPase activity (Paavola, '75) , supporting the view that they are lysosomal in nature. I t thus seems probable that these inclusions are the prime agents responsible for the degradation of cellular constituents during luteolysis. Further, they appear to be the earliest definite indication of regression a t the fine-structural level, corroborating a similar finding in sheep (Gemmell et al., '76 ). This contrasts with other studies in sheep in which the first signs of involution were reported to be nuclear fragmentation (Bjersing et al., '70a ) and mitochondrial changes (Deane et al., '66) . Moreover, in the present study the occurrence of autophagic vacuoles in large numbers throughout involution suggests that autophagy is a prominent mechanism in regression of the corpus luteum of the guinea pig after pregnancy. In an earlier report on guinea pigs (Crombie et al., '711 , autophagic vacuoles were mentioned only briefly. Autophagic vacuoles of varying description also have been reported to occur in regressing luteal cells of sheep (Bjersing et al., '70a, b; Gemmell et al., '76) and humans (van Lennep and Madden, '65; Quatacker, '71) . Although it is generally agreed that these bodies participate in involution, the extent of their involvement has not been fully resolved. Van Lennep and Madden ('65) suggest that they play only a minor role in the overall process of regression. On the other hand, the prominence of autophagic vacuoles during involution in the present study suggests that autophagy may have an important role in the destruction of corpora lutea.

The intricate and double-membrane forms of autophagic vacuoles observed in the present study have not been implicated previously in normal luteolysis. Structures somewhat similar in morphology to the intricate autophagic vacuoles of the current report were present in a figure illustrating regression in sheep luteal cells following hysterectomy (Bjersing et al., '70b) . However, those structures were thought to be related to impaired hormone release, since they were not observed in normal regression (Bjersing et al., '70a) . The only other cell type in which these unusual autophagic vacuoles have been described are macrophages. Pratt et al. ('71) observed inclusions of the intricate type in alveolar macrophages of humans who smoke, and interpreted them to be lysosomes or their derivatives, but not autophagic or heterophagic vacuoles. Mouse peritoneal macrophages, when caused to die by exposure to cannabinoids in vitro (Raz and Goldman, '761, sometimes display bodies similar in appearance to the double-membrane forms of the present study. Although the inclusions described by those authors were identified as autophagic vacuoles, their possible origins were not considered.

In other studies it has been claimed that bodies similar in morphology to the doublemembrane inclusions of the present report report contain the polypeptide, relaxin. Crisp et al. (' 70) noted such bodies in a morphological examination of corpora lutea from humans during pregnancy, and speculated that they might contain relaxin. This speculation was given additional support by Belt et al. ('70, '71) , who observed in sows that somewhat similar bodies were absent during the estrous cycle, lacked ACPase activity and disappeared just prior to parturition, paralleling a rise in serum relaxin. Recently, on morphological grounds, Bagwell ('77) also speculated that similar bodies in gerbil luteal cells of late pregnancy might contain relaxin. However, in marked contrast to the findings of Belt et al. ('70, '71) , the double-membrane and intricate inclusions of the present study are strongly ACPase-positive (Paavola, '751, do not disappear prior to parturition and accumulate in regressing luteal cells during the postpartum period, all of which argue against these bodies being a prime site of relaxin storage. It thus seems more reasonable to suggest, as has been done in this report, that the double-membrane and intricate inclusions observed in luteal cells of guinea pigs participate primarily in intracellular digestive events, presumably autophagy. I t may well be that the morphologically similar bodies observed in these various animals have diverse functions depending on the species, and that their similarity in appearance reflects a common mode of formation and packaging.

The development of these autophagic vacuoles is of considerable interest since their origin has not been firmly established in any species. The membranes circumscribing au-PAAVOLA tophagic vacuoles in other tissues have been described as arising from the Golgi complex (Frank and Christensen, '68; Locke and Sykes, '75) , smooth ER (Novikoff and Shin, '64; Arstila and Trump, '681, GERL (Novikoff, '64) and plasma membrane (van Lennep and Madden, '65; Quatacker, '71) . Images seen in the present study suggest that the membranes of intricate autophagic vacuoles are derived from GERL cisternae, via double-membrane autophagic vacuoles. The proposed developmental sequence follows: GERL cisternae develop a dense content (fig. 21 ). become cupshaped (fig. 22 ), gain a central dense line and leave the Golgi-GERL area (fig. 23 ). These newly-formed, cup-shaped bodies then attach to pre-existing dense bodies (figs. 24, 251, forming double-membrane inclusions. Continued fusion of these double-membrane autophagic vacuoles with each other and with other dense bodies ultimately gives rise to the intricate forms of autophagic vacuoles (figs. 26,27) that are prominent in regressing luteal cells. The cytochemical demonstration of ACPase activity in GERL, and in the doublemembrane and intricate forms of autophagic vacuoles (Paavola, '75) lends additional support to this proposed developmental sequence. The stimulus responsible for the formation of these ACPase-containing autophagic vacuoles is unknown, but several lines of evidence from various species suggest that it may possibly be the luteolysin, prostaglandin Fza (Bagwell et al., '75; Henderson and McNatty, '75; Kaley and Weiner, '75; Koering and Kirton, '73; Stacy et al., '76; Weiner and Kaley, '75) .

Although it seems likely that intricate autophagic vacuoles arise from GERL, the origin of aggregate autophagic vacuoles remains uncertain. Structures clearly intermediate i n form between the mature vacuole and earlier stages were not observed in the present study; therefore, it was not possible to reconstruct the pathway of their formation. There have been various conjectures about the origin of similar bodies (Crombie et al., '71) , but no evidence has been available to substantiate them.

In contrast to the complex types of autophagic vacuoles, which predominate during regression, the simple autophagic vacuoles (fig. 28 ) are few in number during both pregnancy and the postpartum period, and do not seem to increase in aging luteal cells. Therefore, it appears unlikely that they contribute appreciably to the destruction of luteal cells during involution in guinea pigs. Recently, however, it has been reported that these bodies accumulate in regressing luteal cells of sheep a t the end of the estrous cycle (Gemmell et al., '76) .

Two other observations of the present study that merit further comment are the persistence of smooth ER throughout regression and the presence of mitochondria-rich cells in older corpora lutea. In earlier reports in the literature, the behavior of the smooth ER was commonly regarded as a prominent feature of involution. This organelle was usually described as becoming vesicular (Priedkalns and Weber, '68; Bjersing et al., '70a1, vacuolar (van Lennep and Madden, '65; Cavazos et al., '69) or structureless (Crombie et al., '71) . In perfusion-fixed material of the present study, the smooth ER did not show any dramatic changes prior to alterations in other cellular organelles, suggesting that it does not lose its integrity until after being sequestered into autophagic vacuoles or until there is widespread degeneration throughout the cytoplasm. This finding in guinea pigs agrees with that of Deane et al. ('66) on degenerating luteal cells of sheep. It is in contrast to a previous description of luteolysis in the guinea pig (Crombie et al., '71) . The deterioration of the smooth ER in these various early studies may either have been a consequence of fixation by immersion or reflect species differences.

Mitochondria-rich cells, which occurred in aging corpora lutea of the present study, have also been described in regressing corpora lutea of sheep (Bjersing et al., '70a; Gemmell et al., '76) and humans (Adams and Hertig, '69) . Such cells may well arise because of the sequence in which cellular organelles are degraded. During regression, autophagic vacuoles often contain lipid droplets, lysosomes, ER, ribosomes, and ground substance, but mitochondria are conspicuously absent from such structures. Furthermore, mitochondrialaden cells, which are smaller than younger luteal cells, were observed near the end of involution, and generally had a paucity of smooth ER and lipid droplets. The ability of mitochondria to escape autophagy may account for the abundance of this organelle in older luteal cells.

The remaining ultrastructural changes observed in regressing luteal cells of this study are basically similar to those described in various species. For example, the dramatic increase in lipid droplets is one of the most commonly encountered involutive phenomena, and has been described previously in guinea pig (Crombie et al., '711, human (Adams and Hertig, '69) , sheep (Deane et al., '66; Bjersing et al., '70a; Gemmell et al., '761, sow (Cavazos et al., '691, cow (Priedkalns and Weber, '681, hamster (Leavitt et al., '73) and rabbit (Blanchette, '66) . This accumulation of lipid droplets in senescent luteal cells may indicate a decreased utilization of cholesterol esters, since it is known that both cholesterol esterase and cholesterol ester synthetase are decreased under these conditions (Behrman et al., '71) . Some, but not all, of the alterations in mitochondria1 morphology observed here have been described previously, sometimes only briefly, in degenerating luteal cells of guinea pig (Crombie et al., '71; Bourneva, '73) , sheep (Deane et al., '66; Bjersing et al., '70a), mink (Mnller, '73) and hamster (Leavitt et al., '73) . The significance of these changes in the structure of mitochondria is unclear, although these alterations seem to occur in parallel with the changing function of this organelle as it shifts away from its role in steroidogenesis. Mitochondria that are deficient in cytochrome oxidase (Karnovsky, '63) or have been injured (David and Kettler, '61) exhibit somewhat similar morphological alterations. In the present study, lysosome-like bodies increased markedly in quantity as regression progressed. Comparable increases in the number of lysosomes (dense bodies) preceding or during involution have been reported in studies on rabbit (Blanchette, '66) , sow (Cavazos et al., '69) , cow (Priedkalns and Weber, '68) and hamster (Leavitt et al., '73) . However, in one paper on sheep, Gemmell et al. ('76) maintained that lysosomes did not increase during luteolysis.

In conclusion, the observations of the present study, taken together with findings from correlated cytochemical studies (Paavola, '75) suggest that the involution of the corpus luteum of pregnancy guinea pigs involves two processes, autophagy and heterophagy. The destruction of luteal cells involves the orderly sequestration of cellular organelles within autophagic vacuoles, where they are broken down, followed ultimately by the removal of the cell or its remnants by macrophages. Moreover, this regression is characterized by the emergence of "new" structures (autoph-agic vacuoles and pleomorphic lysosomes) , rather than by marked degenerative changes in the pre-existing organelles. The results of this study further indicate that some of the autophagic vacuoles arise from GERL. The aggregate autophagic vacuole, which is common in regressing luteal cells, is enclosed by a single membrane and usually contains numerous spherical structures of varying densities, many of which are myelin figures. X 16.000.

By near term, many of the luteal cell mitochondria show changes in their morphology. In contrast to the rod-shaped mitochondria that characterized earlier stages, mitochondria now display a variety of unusual shapes, including cup-shaped, sinuous and attenuated forms. As shown here, the cupshaped mitochondria encircle each other, as well as other cellular organelles. A particularly sinuous mitochondrion appears at the right of this field. The density of some mitochondria appears to be increased. X 15,000.

One of the most unusual of the polymorphic mitochondria is the extremely long and thin form shown in this micrograph (arrows). Many mitochondria now display cristae that are highly ordered, with the lamellae or tubules lying parallel to each other (arrowhead). X 14,500.

The luteal cell in this micrograph shows many features characteristic of regression, including aggregate (aa) and intricate (ia) autophagic vacuoles, many dense bodies and a highly pleomorphic lysosome (rectangle). Smooth ER tubules and cisternae are abundant and well-preserved, and whorls of smooth ER persist. Nuclear fine structure is unchanged from that of preceding stages. Numerous coated vesicles, many ribosomes and occasional multivesicular bodies occur in luteal cells of this stage.

42 By 16 days postpartum, luteal cells are few in number, but those that remain appear remarkably well-preserved in perfused material. Although the smooth ER in this cell is sparse, the tubules are normal in configuration. Particularly abundant in this field are double-membrane autophagic vacuoles (large arrows), which frequently contain dense bodies in addition to other organelles. Pleomorphic mitochondria abound, and many display crystals within their cristae. An intricate autophagic vacuole (ia) is located a t the center of the field. Microtubules and cisternae of rough ER occur widely throughout the cell. Perichromatin granules (small arrow) persist in the nucleus. X 21,000.43 The large double-membrane autophagic vacuole in this micrograph encloses a smaller double-membrane figure (small arrow), dense bodies and ground substance. The second inclusion (large arrow), limited by a single membrane, contains many small vesicles and several dense bodies, one of which retains its limiting membrane (arrowhead). The third inclusion (double arrows), also enclosed by a single membrane, is filled with heterogeneous dense material. From various views that have beem observed, these three bodies may possibly represent developmental stages from autophagic vacuole to advanced residual body. For example, breakdown of the inner of the two membranes surrounding the large double-membrane autophagic vacuole and partial digestion of the contents might give rise to a structure resembling the second inclusion (large arrow). Continued digestion of the contents might eventually lead to the formation of a residual body, much like the third inclusion illustrated here. X 20.000.

BIBREF59.title: EXPLANATION OF FIGURE 3 Luteal cell, 26 days of pregnancy. At this stage, luteal cells characteristically contain abundant profiles of smooth ER, numerous rod-shaped mitochondria (mi), a well-developed Golgi complex (g), occasional lysosome-like bodies (ly), many free ribosomes and microtubles (arrowheads). The smooth ER membranes, as seen here, are commonly in the form of densely-packed, interweaving tubules that occupy much of the available cytoplasm. The large, spherical nucleus usually displays a number of perichromatin granules (arrows)
BIBREF59.raw_text: EXPLANATION OF FIGURE 3 Luteal cell, 26 days of pregnancy. At this stage, luteal cells characteristically contain abundant profiles of smooth ER, numerous rod-shaped mitochondria (mi), a well-de- veloped Golgi complex (g), occasional lysosome-like bodies (ly), many free ribosomes and microtubles (arrowheads). The smooth ER membranes, as seen here, are common- ly in the form of densely-packed, interweaving tubules that occupy much of the availa- ble cytoplasm. The large, spherical nucleus usually displays a number of perichromatin granules (arrows). X 24,000. PLATE 11

BIBREF60.title: EXPLANATION OF FIGURE 41 Luteal cell, ten days postpartum. Mitochondria-rich cells, similar to the one shown here, are sometimes observed in the later stages of involution. In these cells, the mitochondria are densely-packed, filling much of the available cytoplasm
BIBREF60.raw_text: EXPLANATION OF FIGURE 41 Luteal cell, ten days postpartum. Mitochondria-rich cells, similar to the one shown here, are sometimes observed in the later stages of involution. In these cells, the mi- tochondria are densely-packed, filling much of the available cytoplasm. Two portions of the nucleus (n) are visible at the right of this micrograph; the remainder of this highly indented nucleus is not included in this field. The smooth ER in this cell ap- pears decreased in amount. A number of dense bodies (db), lipid droplets (Id) and electron-lucent vacuoles (v) are scattered throughout the cytoplasm. X 16,000.

FIGREF0.text: Figures 35 through 39 are of luteal cells at five days postpartum.

TABREF0.text: Figures 1 and 2 are low-power electron micrographs of luteal cells at 26 days of pregnancy and at five days postpartum, and illustrate several of the changes that occur in luteal cell morphology from the time of maximal progesterone secretion through involution. These figures also demonstrate that luteal cells, regardless of age, exhibit a uniform electron-density in corpora lutea fixed by perfusion.1 A t 26 days of gestation, luteal cells contain a large, spherical nucleus (n), and display a variable number of lipid droplets and a few dense bodies Located between the luteal cells are numerous capillaries. Occasional macrophages (m) appear in the field. At five days postpartum, a striking increase in the number of lipid droplets is evident in most luteal cells. The abundant lipid droplets often differ in density and size. Occasionally, much enlarged lipid droplets (long arrows) are noted, which can be compared with normal-sized lipid dropletn (short arrow) in the same cell (the pale ring around the smaller droplet is a whorl of smooth ER). Several luteal cells in this field show a marked increase in the number of large dense bodies (arrowheads). Luteal cell nuclei (n) usually display irregular contours at this stage. Also included in this field are two debris-laden macrophages (m). X
